data.text: When I tour in Europe and if there is a chance or rain, I just keep my rain jacket handy on top of the panniers or backpack. That handles most light rain events. data.text: I live in Florida, and I run very hot...meaning I sweat copiously. I rarely see precipitation below 50¬∞ F/10¬∞ C. Rain gear, for me, is about staying WARM, not dry. With that in mind, my rain gear solutions: Above 70¬∞ F/21¬∞ C: get wet. Make sure I have eye cover for being able to see, both day and night. Between 55¬∞ F/13¬∞ C and 70¬∞ F/21¬∞ C: tri vest (Showers Pass, unfortunately now discontinued), warm liner gloves (cheap acrylic) with a waterproof overmitt, water/wind resistant shoe covers. Between 45¬∞ F/7¬∞ C and 55¬∞ F/13¬∞ C: All of the above, plus arm warmers and long tights. Between 40¬∞ F/4¬∞ C and 45¬∞ F/7¬∞ C: All of the above plus a second set of softshell gloves and bread/newspaper/produce bags between my socks and the shoes as a vapor barrier. Below 40¬∞ F/4¬∞ C: All of the above, plus a balaclava and $0.10 shower cap worn under the helmet. Note that I've only done three or four rides, one of which was three hours at night, in the last category. My fine-tuning there is less precise than in the others. Hope it helps!

data.text: Personally I carry a complete rain gear. Most of the time though, I don't wear all my set. It's just nice to know I have it. I don't ride at all costs but must be prepared to finish up a day in all conditions. Rain gear limits inconveniences but does not avoid them 100%. Bad or worn material got me wet several times, from head to toe.
data.author: Vlady Stroy

data.text: Rain gear for when you finish or find yourself in a 'too cold' type of rain and wind condition. Rain gear can keep away hypothermia and cramping. While cycling there is nearly always 'wet' conditions in your kit. If it is refreshing, adapt to it, but if the rain is driving and miserable consider seeking shelter till it passes especially if lightning.
